Dialogue: Come on, fellas - you know the deal - we agreed to push Maureen's start date so she could get her teeth fixed.

Speaker: denham

Dialogue: Whoa! Carl - slow down!

Dialogue: Is he askin' for more money?

Dialogue: What are you - an idiot? You think they asked De Mille to waste his time on nudie shots? No - they respected the film maker, they showed some class! Not that you'd know what that means - you cheap low-life!

Speaker: zelman
Dialogue: Would you step outside for a moment, Carl?

Speaker: denham

Dialogue: Preston, you have a lot to learn about the motion picture business.

Speaker: zelman
Dialogue: Don't write him off fellas. He's hot- headed sure, but Carl Denham's made some interesting pictures, he's had a lot of ... near success.

Dialogue: This jumped up little turd's gonna bankrupt us.

Dialogue: Mr. Denham - I want you to know that I'm not in the habit of accepting charity from strangers, or for that matter ... taking things that don't belong to me. D DENHAM t was obviously a terrible misunderstanding.

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: mock sincerity) That's awful. Anyway, Ann - may I call you Ann?

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: I'm someone you can trust, Ann. I'm a movie producer.  Believe me, I am on the level, no funny business. Please, sit down - Please ... Please.

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: Singapore. On board ship he meets a mysterious girl. She's beautiful ... she's fragile ... haunted ...

Dialogue: Yes!

Dialogue: Oh really?

Speaker: ann
Dialogue: Well I really -

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: Ann? I'm telling you, You're perfect - look at you! You're the saddest girl I ever met ... you're gonna make `em weep, Ann - you're gonna break their hearts!

Dialogue: See, that's where you're wrong, Mr. Denham, I make people laugh, that's what I do.

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: Ann! Miss Darrow! Please!
I'm offering NHAM DE you money, adventure, fame ... the thrill of a lifetime and a long sea voyage. You wanna read a script? Jack Driscoll's turning in a draft as we speak.

Dialogue: ure. Why - wait! You know him?

Dialogue: Thanks...

Dialogue: So I did ... Sorry about that  Let's start from the beginning.

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Let me just ... It'll just take a second.

Speaker: jack

Dialogue: Knock knock! We can't have our leading lady deprived of the necessities of life. to PRESTON) Do me a favour - run a bottle down to Jack. It'll fend off his migraine.

Dialogue: Zoos ... circus ...  Careful! Camel have bad accident on floor. Stain unremovable ...

Dialogue: Doing it now, Mr. Hayes.

Dialogue: How about you return Mr. Driscoll's pen first?

Dialogue: No, it's okay.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: It's just he likes it down here, it's where I found him ... four years ago ... stowed away in one of them cages. His arm was broken in two places, he was wilder than half the animals in here. Still won't tell me where he came from - all I know, it wasn't any place good.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: You gotta straighten up. You don't want to be on this ship for the rest of your life.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: I do.

Dialogue: No, you don't, Jimmy. You wanna get yourself educated. Give yourself some options. Take this serious.

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: I do, Mr. Hayes, I do! Look, I've been readin'.

Dialogue: Where did you get this?

Speaker: jimmy
Dialogue: I borrowed it ...

Dialogue: It's nice to meet you Mr. Driscoll - I'm actually quite familiar with your work.  I've read everything you've ever written.

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: I don't care, Mike! You're the sound recordist - make it work.

Dialogue: Delighted to meet you, ma'am. And may I say what a lovely dress.

Dialogue: Oh! This old thing! I just - threw it on!

Dialogue: Actually - I am quite familiar with your work.

Dialogue: Yes, and what I most admire - is the way you have captured the voice of the common people.

Dialogue: Well - that's my job.

Dialogue: ait a second, we're killing off the First Mate?

Dialogue: There's nothing officially wrong with it. Because technically it hasn't been discovered yet.

Dialogue: All right everyone, from the top.   And ... action!

Dialogue: I know ... I should have -

Dialogue: I was nervous.

Dialogue: hen you've nothing to lose.

Dialogue: I wouldn't be so sure of that.

Speaker: preston
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: lumpy
Dialogue: Seven years ago, me and Mr Hayes - we were working our passage on a Norwegian barque.

Speaker: hayes
Dialogue: We picked up a castaway - found him in the water - he'd been drifting for days.

Speaker: lumpy
Dialogue: His ship had run aground on an island, way West of Sumatra. An island hidden in fog. He spoke of a huge wall, built so long ago - no one knew who had made it ... A wall a hundred foot high ... as strong today as it was, ages ago.

Speaker: preston
Dialogue: Why did they build the wall?

Speaker: lumpy
Dialogue: The castaway - he spoke of a creature, neither beast nor man, but something monstrous, living behind that wall...

Speaker: denham
Dialogue: A lion or a tiger. A man-eater. That's how all these stories start.

Speaker: preston
Dialogue: What else did he say?

Speaker: lumpy
Dialogue: Nothing. We found him the next morning ... he'd stuck a knife through his heart.

Dialogue: orry fellas, you'll have to do better than that. Monsters belong in B movies!

Dialogue: If you find this place -
